metadata.titleEn: Multi-scale surface flux and meteorological elements observation dataset in the Hai River Basin (Huailai station-automatic weather station-10m tower, 2015)
metadata.description:
The data set contains the observation data of the 10m tower automatic meteorological station on December 31, 2015 on January 1, 2015 at solstice.The station is located in east garden town, huailai county, hebei province.The latitude and longitude of the observation point is 115.7880E, 40.3491N, and the altitude is 480m.
The automatic weather station is installed on a 10m tower, the acquisition frequency is 30s, and the output time is 10min.The observation factors include air temperature and relative humidity (5m), and the direction is due north.The wind speed (10m), the wind direction (10m), the direction is due to the north;Air pressure (installed in waterproof box);Rainfall (10m);The four-component radiation (5m), the direction is due to the south;The infrared surface temperature (5m), the arm is facing south, and the probe is facing vertically downward.The soil temperature and humidity probe was buried at 1.5m to the south of the meteorological tower. The buried depth of the soil temperature probe was 0cm, 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 20cm, 40cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm. The buried depth of the soil moisture sensor was 2cm, 4cm, 10cm, 10cm, 10cm, 10cm, 20cm, 80cm, 120cm and 160cm.The average soil temperature was buried 2,4 cm underground.Soil hot flow plates (3) are buried in the ground 6cm.
Processing and quality control of observation data :(1) ensure 144 data per day (every 10min). If data is missing, it will be marked by -6999;(2) eliminate the moments with duplicate records;(3) data that is obviously beyond the physical meaning or the range of the instrument is deleted;(4) the format of date and time is unified, and the date and time are in the same column.For example, the time is: 10:30 on June 10, 2015.Data missing due to damage of charging controller from May 30 to June 5 and October 1 to October 9.Soil heat flux G1 due to the heat flux plate problem, the data of April 19 solstice on May 20 was missing.
Data released by the automatic weather station include:Date/Time, air temperature and humidity observation (Ta_5m, RH_5m) (℃, %), wind speed (Ws_10m) (m/s), wind direction (WD) (°), pressure (hpa), precipitation (Rain) (mm), four-component radiation (DR, UR, DLR, ULR, Rn) (W/m2), surface radiation temperature (IRT_1, IRT_2) (℃),Soil heat flux (Gs_1, Gs_2, Gs_3) (W/m2), multi-layer soil moisture (Ms_2cm, Ms_4cm, Ms_10cm, Ms_20cm, Ms_40cm, Ms_80cm, Ms_120cm, Ms_160cm) (%), multi-layer soil temperature (Ts_2cm, Ts_4cm, Ts_10cm, Ts_20cm, Ts_40cm, Ts_80cm, Ts_120cm, Ts_160cm) (℃), average soil temperature TCAV (℃).
Please refer to Guo et al. (2020) for information of observation test or site, and Liu et al. (2013) for data processing.

background: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a key factor in surface flux estimations with remote sensing algorithms and/or land surface models. Originally, z0m is defined as the height where the wind speed, given by the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile, becomes zero. According to numerous observations, the variation range of z0m over different surfaces is large, from an order of 1.0 m over urban areas and mountainous areas, to an order of 0.1 mm or even 0.01 mm over smooth water body surfaces, ice and snow surfaces. The traditional way to calculate z0m is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory, using wind profile measurements. In practical applications, especially for remote sensing models and land surface models, it is difficult to obtain z0m for a local or regional scale based only on station observations. Former researchers have proposed some parameterizations between the aerodynamic roughness length and the land surface properties [e.g., vegetation height, leaf area index (LAI), etc.], since wind turbulence is controlled by the structure and spacing of roughness elements (plants and other obstacles) on the land surface, and z0m describes the roughness characteristics of a surface.
research objective: Based on the data of the Xiaotangshan Experiment (Changping District of Beijing, China), which was conducted in 2002, 2004, and 2005 respectively, the objectives of this paper are: (1) to calculate z0m over different surfaces and analyze the directional characteristics of z0m over heterogeneous surfaces using an analytical footprint model; (2) to relate the estimated z0m over heterogeneous surfaces to roughness element characteristic factors, and present a heuristic parameterization of z0m as a reference for model parameterizations.
challenges: More data is needed for further discussions.
methods: This paper calculates z0m over several land surfaces, with 3 years of experimental data from Xiaotangshan. Individual z0m over each surface component (patch) is calculated firstly with the characteristic parameters of the roughness elements (vegetation height, leaf area index, etc.), then z0m over the whole experimental field is aggregated, using the footprint weighting method.
dataset: This experiment was carried out at the Xiaotangshan Experimental Station for Precision Agriculture (40°10′41′′N, 116°26′52′′E, 35 m above sea level) in Beijing. The observation period in 2002 was from 26 March to 23 April and the land cover was bare soil. In 2004, the experiment was carried out from 30 May to 7 July. In the southern sub-plot field, the land cover was bare soil between 30 May and 11 June, while the maize plants started emerging around 12 June. In 2005, the experiment was from 1 May to 10 June and the experimental layout was almost the same as that in 2004.
findings: The results show that z0m is direction-dependent, mainly due to the heterogeneity of the size and spatial distribution of the roughness elements inside the source area along different wind directions.

background: Sensible and latent heat fluxes are important indicators reflecting the intensity of heat and water vapor exchange between the land and atmosphere, influencing the energy balance between them, providing material, dynamic, and thermal sources for weather systems of different scales, and affecting the water cycle process between the land and atmosphere. Currently, there are many traditional methods for observing surface fluxes, such as the Eddy-Covariance system (EC), Bowen ratio-energy balance system, and aerodynamic methods. Among these, the Eddy-Covariance system is internationally recognized as the most reliable method for observing surface fluxes; however, its observation scale is relatively small, with spatial representativeness only on the order of tens to hundreds of meters. The Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS), in contrast to traditional Eddy-Covariance systems, can obtain average sensible heat fluxes at a regional scale (from hundreds of meters to several kilometers). Because the observation scale of LAS aligns well with satellite pixel scales and the grid scales of numerical weather prediction and climate models, the observations from LAS can serve as ground truth at the pixel/grid scale for remote sensing estimation models, numerical weather prediction models, and climate models, thereby optimizing and validating these models. The observation principle of LAS is based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST), which, combined with the atmospheric refractive index structure parameter C2n and related meteorological data, utilizes the stability universal function fT related to the temperature structure parameter C2T to obtain the regional average sensible heat flux at the surface.
research objective: Using the LAS-related data from Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and Arou Station (January to June and October to November), the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) in LAS observations was analyzed, and a quantitative assessment method for the applicability of MOST was explored.
challenges: Due to the influence of underlying surface cover types, flatness, water and thermal conditions, and weather conditions, it is difficult to achieve the ideal assumption of uniformity in practice. Currently, domestic research on atmospheric similarity theory mainly focuses on the similarity relationships of wind, temperature profiles, and turbulence variance. However, there is relatively little research on the similarity between temperature structure parameters and turbulence characteristics in scintillation methods.
methods: Before analyzing the applicability of the MOST theory to LAS data, preliminary processing of EC and LAS data is conducted. LAS, EC, and AWS data from the Guantao Station (January to December 2009) and the Aru Station (January to June and October to November) are selected.
dataset:
Guantao Station (36°30′54″N, 115°07′39″E) is located in Hezhai Village, Guantao County, Hebei Province. Its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of farmland, including winter wheat, corn, and cotton, with winter wheat and corn being rotated. The growth period for winter wheat is from October to June of the following year, while corn grows from June to October, and cotton grows from May to October, making it a typical farmland underlying surface of the North China Plain. In the LAS source area, winter wheat (corn) accounts for about 45% of the area, while cotton accounts for about 47%. 

Arou Station (38°02′40″N, 100°27′53″E) is located in the valley area upstream of the Heihe River, and its observation site and surrounding underlying surface consist of typical alpine grassland, which is relatively flat. The vegetation height in the source area can reach 0.2 to 0.3 meters during the growing season.
findings: (1) Under unstable conditions, large-scale vortex motion, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales can significantly affect the applicability of the MOST theory; (2) Two new methods for determining the applicability of the MOST theory have been established, namely factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, and it has been verified that these two judgment methods are reasonable and reliable.

background: For surface flux measurements, large aperture scintillometer (LAS) has become more and more popular in recent years. Compared with traditional observation techniques, it can measure surface fluxes on a larger scale (500 m to 10 km). At present, LAS observation is not common in China.
research objective: The daily and monthly variation of HLAS is analyzed. And the observation differences between eddy covariance system and LAS, need to be studied further combined with footprint model and energy unbalance of eddy covariance system observation.
challenges: There is much less agreement on the form which universal stability function fT should take. Further more, since the iteration process of HLAS can not be convergence when low wind speed and very stable conditions appearing at night, Wm \ - 5 is specified.
findings: Sensible heat flux (H) calculation with the LAS data of above measurements shows that the beam height of LAS and wind speed are sensitive factors for sensible heat flux measurement (HLAS), zero-plane displacement height is crucial unless the beam height is much larger than it, and Bowen ratio needs to be determined accurately over wet surface, while air temperature, air pressure and aerodynamic roughness length are not sensitive for HLAS. According to the observations mentioned above, LAS can measure surface fluxes both over homogeneous and heterogeneous surfaces.

Definition.Question: What is the importance of 'aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)' in surface flux estimations?
Definition.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is a crucial factor in surface flux estimations using remote sensing algorithms or land surface models. It is defined as the height where the wind speed becomes zero, based on the extrapolation of the logarithmic wind profile. The variation range of z0m over different surfaces can be significant, affecting the accuracy of flux estimations.

Definition.Question: How does the 'Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST)' apply to data collection in meteorological studies?
Definition.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is used in meteorological studies to relate observed atmospheric parameters to surface fluxes. It is applied in methods like the Eddy-Covariance system and Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) to observe surface fluxes by utilizing stability functions and refractive index structure parameters of the atmosphere. MOST helps in determining the regional average of sensible heat flux by connecting measured data with theoretical models.

Definition.Question: What challenges are associated with the use of 'Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS)' for surface flux measurements?
Definition.Answer: The use of Large Aperture Scintillometer (LAS) for surface flux measurements presents challenges such as ensuring the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory under varying conditions, like low wind speeds and stable atmospheric conditions. Additionally, factors like beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height are crucial for accurate measurements, requiring careful calibration and consideration of environmental conditions.

Comparison.Question: How do the data collection techniques used in automatic meteorological stations compare with those utilized in large aperture scintillometer (LAS) methods in terms of spatial scale and data representation?
Comparison.Answer: Automatic meteorological stations, as in the metadata, capture detailed point data such as air temperature, humidity, wind speed, and soil moisture at a specific location, with high temporal frequency but limited spatial representation. In contrast, LAS methods, as described in the papers, measure surface fluxes over larger spatial scales (several hundred meters to kilometers), making them more suitable for regional assessments, though they provide less localized data.

Interpretation.Question: How can the variability in aerodynamic roughness length across different surfaces be interpreted in relation to land surface properties and their influence on data collection methods?
Interpretation.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) varies significantly across different surfaces, and this can be interpreted by considering the land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index. This variability influences data collection methods by requiring parameterizations that account for the roughness elements' structure and spacing, as these factors control wind turbulence and hence affect remote sensing and land surface model estimations.

Interpretation.Question: What are the implications of missing data due to instrument failure on the interpretation of meteorological trends within datasets, and how might researchers address these gaps?
Interpretation.Answer: Missing data due to instrument failure can hinder the interpretation of meteorological trends by introducing gaps in continuous observations, which are critical for accurate analysis. Researchers can address these gaps by using data quality control measures, such as marking missing data with specific codes, and employing statistical techniques to estimate or interpolate missing values based on available data patterns and adjacent observations.

Interpretation.Question: What factors should be considered when integrating large aperture scintillometer data with other meteorological datasets to enhance the understanding of surface fluxes over heterogeneous landscapes?
Interpretation.Answer: When integrating large aperture scintillometer data with other meteorological datasets, factors such as beam height, wind speed, and zero-plane displacement height should be considered, as they significantly affect the measurement of sensible heat flux. Additionally, understanding the heterogeneity of the landscape and ensuring compatibility with the footprint model and energy balance considerations are crucial for accurately interpreting surface fluxes.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors cause challenges in collecting accurate surface flux data using remote sensing algorithms and land surface models?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: Challenges in collecting accurate surface flux data arise due to the difficulty in obtaining aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) for local or regional scales from station observations. The variation of z0m across different surfaces, from urban areas to smooth water bodies, adds complexity. The parameterization of z0m concerning land surface properties like vegetation height and leaf area index influences the accuracy of surface flux estimations.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What causes the need for further data collection to improve the understanding of directional dependencies in aerodynamic roughness length (z0m)?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The need for further data collection arises from the direction-dependent nature of z0m, influenced by the heterogeneity of roughness elements such as size and spatial distribution within the source area along different wind directions. This complexity necessitates more data to explore and parameterize these dependencies accurately for model applications.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of using automatic weather stations with high-frequency data collection on the accuracy and granularity of meteorological datasets in agricultural regions?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Using automatic weather stations with high-frequency data collection, such as those collecting data every 30 seconds and outputting every 10 minutes, enhances the accuracy and granularity of meteorological datasets. This allows for detailed monitoring of variables like air temperature, relative humidity, wind speed, and more, which are crucial for understanding microclimatic variations and their impacts on agricultural areas.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to analyze the directional characteristics and parameterizations of aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) over heterogeneous surfaces using experimental data?
Goal Orientation.Answer: Analyzing the directional characteristics and parameterizations of z0m is important for improving the accuracy of remote sensing algorithms and land surface models. Understanding how z0m varies with land surface properties such as vegetation height and distribution helps in better representing surface roughness in models, which is critical for accurate predictions of wind profiles and surface energy exchanges.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How are aerodynamic roughness length values (z0m) calculated and parameterized using observational data from multiple land surface types?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length values (z0m) are calculated by first determining z0m over each surface component (patch) using characteristic parameters of roughness elements like vegetation height and leaf area index. Then, z0m over the entire experimental field is aggregated using the footprint weighting method to account for directional characteristics and heterogeneity.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What methodological approaches are used to assess the applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory for large aperture scintillometer data in different environmental conditions?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: The Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory applicability is assessed by analyzing LAS data alongside EC and AWS data, focusing on factors like large-scale eddy movements, atmospheric turbulence development, and temperature scales under unstable conditions. Two new methods—factor analysis and temperature structure parameter method—are established for quantitatively judging the theory's applicability, ensuring their reliability through validation.

Enablement.Question: What methodologies allow the integration of aerodynamic roughness length estimations into remote sensing algorithms and land surface models at regional scales?
Enablement.Answer: The integration is enabled through parameterizations between aerodynamic roughness length and land surface properties such as vegetation height and leaf area index, as wind turbulence is influenced by the structure and arrangement of roughness elements on the land surface.

Enablement.Question: How does the use of large aperture scintillometers (LAS) facilitate the measurement of surface fluxes over larger areas compared to traditional methods?
Enablement.Answer: LAS can measure surface fluxes over larger scales (500m to 10km) by providing regional average sensible heat flux values that match satellite pixel scales and numerical weather prediction grid scales, thus serving as ground truth for optimizing and validating remote sensing models and climate models.

Expectation.Question: Why might data collection methods for surface flux measurements be challenging when using traditional techniques like the eddy covariance system compared to large aperture scintillometers?
Expectation.Answer: The eddy covariance system, while reliable, has a small observational scale with spatial representativeness of only tens to hundreds of meters. In contrast, large aperture scintillometers can capture regional scale fluxes over hundreds of meters to kilometers, making them more suitable for matching satellite pixel scales and model grid scales. Additionally, the eddy covariance system can face energy balance issues and requires a thorough understanding of footprint models to interpret data accurately over heterogeneous surfaces.

Expectation.Question: Why might a dataset focusing on aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) require additional data for comprehensive analysis?
Expectation.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is highly variable across different surfaces due to the heterogeneity in size and distribution of roughness elements, such as vegetation height and leaf area index. This variability makes it challenging to obtain accurate z0m measurements for local or regional scales based solely on station observations. More data is necessary to accurately parameterize z0m and relate it to surface characteristics, aiding in model parameterizations for remote sensing and land surface models.

Expectation.Question: Why is the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) not always applicable for analyzing data from large aperture scintillometers?
Expectation.Answer: The applicability of the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory (MOST) is influenced by factors such as surface cover type, flatness, hydrometeorological conditions, and weather. These factors impact the assumption of horizontal homogeneity needed for MOST. Large eddies, atmospheric turbulence, and temperature scales also significantly affect MOST's applicability under unstable conditions. Therefore, new methods for determining MOST applicability, such as factor analysis and temperature structure parameter methods, are necessary to ensure reliable analysis.

Judgmental.Question: How can the integration of different data collection techniques enhance the reliability of surface flux estimations over various land surfaces?
Judgmental.Answer: Integration of different data collection techniques, such as combining eddy covariance systems with large aperture scintillometers, can enhance reliability by providing complementary observations that cover different spatial scales. This approach allows for a more comprehensive analysis of surface fluxes, addressing the limitations of each method individually and enabling cross-validation and optimization of remote sensing and land surface models.

Request/Directive.Question: Please analyze different data collection methods for measuring aerodynamic roughness length and discuss their applicability over various surfaces.
Request/Directive.Answer: Aerodynamic roughness length (z0m) is traditionally calculated using wind profile measurements based on the Monin-Obukhov Similarity Theory. However, for remote sensing models and land surface models, obtaining z0m for local or regional scales based solely on station observations is challenging. A possible method is using parameterizations between aerodynamic roughness length and land surface properties, such as vegetation height and leaf area index, which describe the roughness characteristics of a surface.

Request/Directive.Question: Please explore data processing and quality control measures necessary for ensuring reliable meteorological and surface flux data collection.
Request/Directive.Answer: Data processing and quality control measures include ensuring the completeness of data by checking for 144 data points per day (every 10 minutes), marking missing data with -6999, and removing duplicate records. Additionally, data that is physically meaningless or beyond instrument range is deleted, and a consistent date and time format is maintained. Specific data loss periods are noted, such as during equipment malfunctions or maintenance.
